content.text: Calculate the size of the resultant horizontal force on the lorry
size of resultant force = .........N
Describe the effect of a horizontal resultant force of zero on the speed of the lorry
Put a tick \((\checkmark)\) in one box
speed increases to a higher constant speed
speed stays the same
speed decreases to a lower constant speed
speed decreases to zero
Fig. 1.1 shows a lorry moving on a straight road. The arrows represent the horizontal forces acting on the lorry. These forces act along the same straight line
Calculate the total stopping distance when the speed of the motorcycle is \(20 \text{m / s}\)
total stopping distance = .........m
Suggest one factor that could increase the total stopping distance
The speed of the motorcycle in Fig. 1.2 is \(20 \text{m / s}\)
The rider reacts to a sudden change in the traffic ahead
He stops as quickly as possible by applying the brakes
The total stopping distance is made up of the distance travelled while the rider is reacting and the distance travelled when the brakes are applied
Fig. 1.3 shows information about stopping when the speed of the motorcycle is \(20 \text{m / s}\)
The weight of child A is 125N
Calculate the mass of child A. Include the unit in your answer
mass of child A = .........unit .........
Fig. 2.1 shows child A and child B sitting in positions which balance the see-saw horizontally
Using the information in Fig. 2.1, determine the distance \(X\)
distance \(X =\) .........m
Fig. 2.1 shows two children sitting on a see-saw
The person in Fig. 2.2 is pushing a child on a swing
State the name of the force that acts against the motion of the swing
State the term used for energy gained by the blocks when they are lifted onto the platform
State how the energy gained by 40 blocks when lifted by the man compares with the energy gained by 40 blocks when lifted by the machine
A man lifts 40 blocks onto a platform, as shown in Fig. 3.1
He lifts 10 blocks at once and does this four times
A machine can lift 40 blocks at once onto the same platform, as shown in Fig. 3.2
10 blocks
Here are descriptions of four situations
Indicate the situations in which work is done
Put a tick \((\checkmark)\) in each correct box

table.html:
A child is sitting at the top of the stairs.
A picture is hanging on a wall.
A student is stretching a spring.
A person is moving a chair.

content.text: Electrical appliances transfer energy. Some of the energy transferred is useful
Draw a line from each electrical appliance to the correct useful energy output
Only draw **three** lines
Some vehicles have wide tyres so that they can drive over soft mud
Explain why the wide tyres enable these vehicles to drive over soft mud
State what is in the space at Y above the mercury
Complete the following statement to describe the use of a mercury barometer
A mercury barometer measures
Fig. 4.1 shows a mercury barometer
State how the pressure of the water at hole 2 compares with the pressure of the water at hole 3
Draw on Fig. 4.2 to show the stream of water flowing from hole 1
The diagram in Fig. 4.2 shows a tall can containing water
The can has three identical holes 1, 2 and 3 on one side, one above the other in a vertical line, as shown in Fig. 4.2
Water is shown flowing out of hole 2 and hole 3
Fig. 5.1 shows diagrams of the arrangement of molecules in three states of matter and shows descriptions of how the molecules move
State how the increase in temperature affects the motion of the air molecules in the tyre
State how the increase in temperature changes the pressure of the air in the tyre
A bicycle tyre contains air. The tyre is sealed and does not leak
The temperature of the air in the tyre increases by \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The volume of the tyre does **not** change
Add the missing labels to Fig. 5.2
The thermometer in Fig. 5.2 is designed to measure a range of temperatures from \(0^\circ \mathrm{C}\) to \(100^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
State the name of a suitable liquid for use in this thermometer
Describe and explain the changes in the thermometer in Fig. 5.2 when the temperature of the liquid increases
Fig. 5.2 shows a liquid-in-glass thermometer
Fig. 6.1 shows an electric kettle containing cold water
The metal heating element heats the water
Explain how thermal energy from the heating element is transferred to all the water in the kettle
A student fills each can with hot water. The initial temperature of the water is \(85^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
The student records the temperature of the water in each can every 30 seconds for 10 minutes
Suggest which can of water will cool more quickly. Give a reason for your answer
suggestion
reason
Suggest and explain **two** changes to can B that reduce thermal energy loss to the surroundings
change 1
change 2
Fig. 6.2 shows two similar metal cans. The only difference is the surface. Can A has a dull black surface and can B has a shiny white surface
Complete the following sentences about light
Use words from the list
**atomic** **blue** **three** **electromagnetic**
**electronic** **violet** **five** **red** **seven**
Light is part of a spectrum of radiation called the .............................................. spectrum
A glass prism disperses white light into ............................................ colours
The colour of light that is refracted least is
State which angle A, B, C or D is the angle of incidence. ........................................
State which angle A, B, C or D is the angle of reflection. ........................................
Fig. 7.1 shows light reflected by a plane mirror
Fig. 8.1 shows the electrical symbols for some circuit components
Identify the circuit component for each electrical symbol
Draw a line from each electrical symbol to the name of the circuit component
Calculate the potential difference (p.d.) across the fixed resistor
potential difference = .........V
State the name of the device for measuring potential difference
Show how the student connects the device stated in (b)(ii) to measure the p.d. across the fixed resistor. Draw the correct symbol and connections on Fig. 8.2
A student connects the circuit shown in Fig. 8.2. The value of the fixed resistor is \(20\Omega\)
The switch is closed. The reading on the ammeter is 0.30A
A clamp and stand hold a soft-iron bar above a bench. A coil of wire is wrapped round the soft-iron bar. The coil of wire is part of an electric circuit. Fig. 9.1 shows the arrangement
Switch S is closed. A student holds a soft-iron disc close to the bar and releases the disc. The disc becomes attached to the bar as shown in Fig. 9.1
Explain why the soft-iron disc is attracted to the soft-iron bar
Switch S is closed. The soft-iron arm is attracted to the soft-iron bar
Explain why the bell operates when the switch S is opened
The switch S is closed. The soft-iron arm is attracted to the soft-iron bar
The battery in the circuit containing the soft-iron bar becomes fully discharged
State and explain whether the bell operates
The circuit in Fig. 9.1 is used to operate a bell in a different circuit, as shown in Fig. 9.2
Describe an experiment to show that a force acts on a current-carrying conductor placed in a magnetic field. You may draw a diagram to help your answer
Fig. 11.1 represents the structure of four atoms P, Q, R and S
State which **two** atoms are isotopes of the same element and explain your answer
and
explanation
State an example of the damage that may be caused by X-rays
State and explain how radiographers can be protected from damage caused by X-rays
Radiographers use X-ray machines in hospitals. X-rays can cause damage to living things
Deduce the type of radiation emitted by the radioactive source
The radioactive source is removed. The meter shows a reading of 3 counts per second
State why the meter does not show a reading of zero counts per second
A radioactive source is placed near to a detector, as shown in Fig. 11.2
The meter shows a reading of 239 counts per second
A sheet of paper is placed between the detector and the radioactive source. The meter shows a reading of 240 counts per second
The sheet of paper is removed and a thin sheet of aluminium is placed between the detector and the radioactive source. The meter shows a reading of 3 counts per second
